document: Software Evolution and Maintenance (Chapter 6: Impact Analysis) by Tripathy & Naik

questions.question: The maintenance process is started by performing impact analysis. [cite: 29]
Impact analysis is only used to analyze source code and does not affect requirements or design documentation. [cite: 43]
The Starting Impact Set (SIS) is the initial set of objects presumed to be impacted by a software Change Request. [cite: 58]
Traceability refers to tracing dependent artifacts within the same model is known as external traceability. [cite: 50]
The Candidate Impact Set (CIS) is the set of objects estimated to be impacted according to a certain impact analysis approach. [cite: 59]
The Discovered Impact Set (DIS) contains objects that were already identified in the Candidate Impact Set. [cite: 60]
The Actual Impact Set (AIS) represents the set of objects actually changed as a result of performing a Change Request. [cite: 61]
The False Positive Impact Set (FPIS) is defined as (CIS U DIS) \ AIS. [cite: 63]
Recall is computed as the ratio of (CIS ∩ AIS) to |AIS|. [cite: 83]
If the Discovered Impact Set (DIS) is empty, the value of recall is 1. [cite: 84]
Precision is computed as the ratio of (CIS ∩ AIS) to |CIS|. [cite: 85, 86]
For an empty False Positive Impact Set (FPIS), the value of precision is 0. [cite: 87]
If the Actual Impact Set is equal to the Candidate Impact Set, both recall and precision are 1. [cite: 88]
Adequacy of an impact analysis approach is its ability to identify all affected elements to be modified. [cite: 97]
Ideally, the Candidate Impact Set should be a subset of the Actual Impact Set (CIS ⊆ AIS). [cite: 98]
Inclusiveness is a performance metric used to express adequacy. [cite: 100]
Sharpness is the ability of an approach to produce a CIS that is as close to AIS as possible. [cite: 119]
Adherence is the ability of an approach to produce a CIS which is as close to AIS as possible. [cite: 119]
It is easy to fully automate the concept assignment problem because programs and concepts occur at identical levels of abstraction. [cite: 130]
Horizontal traceability helps developers understand the relationships among software artifacts in a project. [cite: 46, 137]
